chapter.title: CIPSO Labeled Networking
chapter.para: This lab will show you how to set up CIPSO labeled networking with SSH. When using an SSH server that requires CIPSO labeled networking, both the client and server must have this set up. This means that anyone without CIPSO labeled networking will be unable to log in to a CIPSO enabled MLS SSH connection.

section.title: Switching to the MLS Enabled SSH Server

tr.td: Since the regular SSH server is not labeled networking enabled, you will need to switch to the sshd-mls server. This is controlled by xinetd! First, turn off the regular SSH server:# chkconfig sshd off

By default, sshd-mls runs on port 222. To change this, edit /etc/xinetd.d/sshd-mls and change the value for port. Regardless of which port you want to run this service on, you need to add that port to ssh_port_t. This is accomplished by doing teh following (example assumes port 222):# semanage port -a -t ssh_port_t -p tcp 222
Reboot to enable your changes. Repeate this procedure on the second MLS machine.

Issue the following commands on both machines as root/sysadm_r/SystemLow:netlabelctl cipsov4 add pass dio:1 tags:1 netlabelctl map del default netlabelctl map add default protocol:cipsov4,1 netlabelctl unlbl accept offYou have now enabled CIPSO labeled networking.
At this point, you should be able to ssh between your two MLS machines. On the first system, execute the following:# ssh -p 222 user@machine2Where "user" is your username. This should work.
On machien2, execute the following:ssh -p 222 user@machine1Again, replace "user" with your username. This should work.

On your workstation host, add the following to /etc/hosts:192.168.100.1 machine1.example.com machine1 192.168.100.2 machine2.example.com machine2Attempt to ssh into machine1.example.com from the workstation:# ssh -p 222 user@machine1.example.comYou should not be successful as your workstation host does not have labeled networking.
Reboot both machines and try this exercise again. What happens, and why?

In the previous part of the lab we found ourselves with a machine that once rebooted no longer worked. This is because our netlabel commands are flished with the machine is shutdown. In order to get around this, add the following to /etc/netlabel.rules on both machines:# Turn on labeled networking cipsov4 add pass doi:1 tags:1 map del default map add default protocol:cipsov4,1 unlbl accept off
Once you have done this, enable the netlabel service on boot:# chkconfig netlabel on
Reboot your machines and try "Testing CIPSO Labeled Networking" again. This time everything should work.
